newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan unveils IMF-agreed reform package.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan unveils IMF-agreed reform package.

text.p: Pakistan will slash spending and impose additional taxes under an IMF-approved plan to stabilise and reform the economy, State (central) Bank of Pakistan governor Muhammad Yaqub said on Tuesday.
Yaqub told a news conference that the government planned to narrow the budget deficit by 40 billion rupees through a mixture of spending cuts and additional taxes in 1996/97 (July-June).
Earlier on Tuesday the central bank devalued the rupee 7.86 percent against the dollar and raised its key repurchase (repo) discount rate to 20 percent a year from 17 percent.
Yaqub said 20 to 21 billion rupees would be slashed from "less essential" development expenditure, while six to seven billion rupees would be cut from current spending.
He said no cuts had been made in budget allocations for defence and debt servicing.
Yaqub said more than 13 billion rupees would be raised from additional tax measures, including two billion rupees from an agricultural income tax to be levied by the four provinces.
He said all oil product prices had been increased by 10 percent with immediate effect.
"These reforms have been approved by the prime minister and her cabinet collegues and (the package) is markedly different from the one proposed by the IMF," he said.

A team from the International Monetary Fund is due in Pakistan on Thursday for an economic review that must be completed before the fund releases any further tranches of a stalled $600 million standby loan.
